verb.description: Go or come up (a slope, incline, or staircase), especially by using the feet and sometimes the hands; ascend.
examples: we began to climb the hill
the air became colder as they climbed higher
he climbed up the steps slowly

verb.description: Move with effort, especially into or out of a confined space; clamber.
examples: Howard started to climb out of the front seat
I climbed down a narrow ladder
he climbed to a high bough

noun.description: An ascent, especially of a mountain or hill, by climbing.
examples: the rigorous climb up the mountain

phrases: his job soon had him climbing the walls
It had been a mess and I was climbing the walls and was a little bit bitter.
That's a whole lot better than the two weeks I spent at my parents' house, unable to drive and climbing the walls.
These are very vulnerable children, they are not climbing the walls or anything like that, but they do need a lot of support.
I was bored so it made sense that Stevie was climbing the walls, even though he'd had a lot longer to get used to being without school or people.
origin: Old English climban, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German klimmen, also to clay and cleave.
